texts.definition: The possibility for players to plan how game state values and entities should be able to develop.
markups: <style="Definition">The possibility for players to plan how game state values and entities should be able to develop.</style>

The game elements that are under players control in many games develop over time. Some games let players influence this development through explicit choices and planning besides the direct short-term consequences of their gameplay actions. These games have <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style>.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Part of creating one's characters in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/H%C3%A2rnmaster">Hârnmaster</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fiasco">Fiasco</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style> typically consist of giving them long-term goals, even if they may primarily be long-term in the diegesis. This also applies for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style>, especially for those that span several events, e.g <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/College%20of%20Wizardry">College of Wizardry</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Krigshj%C3%A4rta">Krigshjärta</link></style>, and campaigns using the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mind's%20Eye%20Theatre">Mind's Eye Theatre</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Strategy%20Games">Strategy Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Master%20of%20Orion">Master of Orion</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> encourage players to put together long-term plans for how their civilizations should develop. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Multiplayer%20Online%20Battle%20Arena%20Games">Multiplayer Online Battle Arena Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients%20series">Defense of the Ancients series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/League%20of%20Legends">League of Legends</link></style> show how planned development can be important even in games where each game instance last for less than an hour typically.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> is typically introduced in games to let players have control over some game elements, e.g. <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>.

More concretely, <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> requires players to be given control over the development of some part of the game state overtime. This makes <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> an important supporting pattern for <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> to be possible. The development can in its simplest form relate just to <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> goals or how players can get <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>. However, richer planning can be allowed by supporting <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> (which naturally require the presence of <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> also). A less common alternative is to allow players to plan the development of <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>. The actual development typically takes place as effects of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>. The actual gameplay actions resulting of these depend on the type of game and the type of development, but <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> are a class of actions that can signify <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style>. As omnipotent controllers of games, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can make all these options possible in games but can also be the ones that cause gameplay events that directly cause <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style>.

A number of patterns can modify how <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> can occur given it is possible. <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> typically lets the scale for <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> be larger than otherwise and can more clearly make work regarding this into <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goals</link></style> removes the freedom from players to choose what goals to plan for but not necessarily their ability to plan for it. <style="Link"><link="dynamic-goal-characteristics">Dynamic Goal Characteristics</link></style> can require players to change their plans as the game context changes and <style="Link"><link="unknown-goals">Unknown Goals</link></style> make it a challenge simply to figure out what the goals are so one can start the planning. Linking particular developments to goals that are <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style> in relation to each other forces players to choose between these.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

The use of <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> often requires that players can access information about what development is possible. This may be provided both from within <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and through <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

Allowing <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> is a way for letting players modify <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. However, the presence of <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can also hinder the freedom players have regarding this, so the patterns can work against each other also.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

Letting players have <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> have several consequences on game designs. It lets players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>, aim for specific <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, choose their own <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player-Defined Goals</link></style>, and can strengthen their <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> with the game elements they can develop. Working toward these are <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> with can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and motivate <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, potentially in the form of pure <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style>. While <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> can cause players to have <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> they have, i.e. they may be under an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illusion%20of%20Influence">Illusion of Influence</link></style>, it can support the perception that they game elements under their control have an <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> can cause players to view other parts of the game design differently. <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> can become goals to achieve, especially if one aims at particular <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> but can also steer the development towards these so the patterns affect each other. It may motivate players to adjust their <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> so it diegetically fits the planned development. Further, <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style>] modifies how <style="Link"><link="team-development">Team Development</link></style> functions when they pattern affects members of <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>.

Having <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> may cause <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> in order to achieve the planned development, but the presence of <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> unrelated to such planning works against it. It can also cause <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> since gameplay options provide may set different parts of the planned development against each other or may work against what is best from a short-term perspective or one related to winning a game.

In games where the game instances go on for long period of times, e.g. in games with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, the work players to both in planning and actual gameplay actions performed towards having <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> can be seen as <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> and provide players with a clear measure of <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> for them. However, <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> is not the only way for <style="CurrentLink">Player-Planned Development</style> to support <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>, it can equally validly be provided through having <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> for which players can plan their development.
